Front: What are the three components needed to declare a class variable/field?
Back: Access modifier, Field type, Field name

Front: What does the 'public' access modifier mean?
Back: The field is accessible from all classes

Front: What does the 'private' access modifier mean?
Back: The field is accessible only within its own class

Front: What does the 'protected' access modifier mean?
Back: The field is accessible within a class package (directory with related classes)

Front: What is the size and range of a byte variable?
Back: 1 byte (8 bits), range: -128 to 127

Front: What is the size and range of an int variable?
Back: 4 bytes (32 bits), range: -2³¹ to 2³¹-1

Front: What is the size and range of a double variable?
Back: 8 bytes (64 bits), range: ±1.7×10³⁰⁸

Front: What is the size of a char variable?
Back: 2 bytes (16 bits) for Unicode characters

Front: What is the size of a boolean variable?
Back: 1 bit, holds true or false

Front: What is the primitive types ordering from smallest to largest?
Back: byte → short → int → long → float → double

Front: What is implicit type casting?
Back: Automatic conversion from smaller to larger types (widening)

Front: What is explicit type casting?
Back: Manual conversion using (type) syntax (narrowing)

Front: What happens when casting from double to int?
Back: The number is truncated, not rounded: (int)2.9 = 2

Front: How do you preserve decimal places in division?
Back: Cast at least one operand to double: double result = x / (double)y;

Front: What are the default initializations for instance variables?
Back: boolean: false, numbers: 0, char: space, objects: null

Front: Are local variables automatically initialized?
Back: No, local variables must be explicitly initialized by the programmer

Front: What is the difference between == and .equals() for strings?
Back: == compares memory addresses, .equals() compares content

Front: What are the logical operators in Java?
What is short-circuit evaluation?
Back: && stops if first is false, || stops if first is true

Front: What is the syntax for if-else statements?
Back: if (condition) { } else if (condition) { } else { }

Front: What is the syntax for switch statements?
Back: switch (expression) { case value: break; default: break; }

Front: What types can be used in switch expressions?
Back: char, int, short, byte, or (Java 7+) String

Front: What happens if you omit break in switch?
Back: Execution falls through to the next case

Front: What is the difference between while and do-while?
Back: while checks condition first, do-while executes at least once

Front: What is the syntax for for loops?
Back: for (init; condition; update) { }

Front: What is the syntax for for-each loops?
Back: for (type var : collection) { }

Front: What does break do in loops?
Back: Exits the loop immediately

Front: What does continue do in loops?
Back: Skips to the next iteration

Front: What is method overloading?
Back: Same method name with different parameter lists

Front: What is call-by-value?
Back: Method arguments are copied, not referenced

Front: What is a constructor?
Back: Special method that initializes instance variables, same name as class

Front: Can constructors be overloaded?
Back: Yes, constructors can have different parameter lists

Front: When is a default constructor provided?
Back: When no constructors are defined in the class

Front: How do you create a Scanner object?
Back: Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in);

Front: What does nextInt() do?
Back: Reads an integer from input

Front: What does nextLine() do?
Back: Reads an entire line (until Enter key)

Front: What is the issue with mixing nextInt() and nextLine()?
Back: nextInt() leaves newline in buffer, nextLine() reads it

Front: How do you fix the nextInt()/nextLine() issue?
Back: Add an extra nextLine() to clear the buffer

Front: What does System.out.print() do?
Back: Displays text without adding a newline

Front: What does System.out.println() do?
Back: Displays text and adds a newline

Front: What does System.out.printf() do?
Back: Displays formatted text with format specifiers

Front: What does %d format specifier do?
Back: Formats integers in base 10

Front: What does %f format specifier do?
Back: Formats floating-point numbers

Front: What does %.2f format specifier do?
Back: Formats floating-point numbers with 2 decimal places

Front: What is autoboxing?
Back: Automatic conversion from primitive to wrapper object

Front: What is unboxing?
Back: Automatic conversion from wrapper object to primitive

Front: What does Integer.parseInt() do?
Back: Converts String to int primitive

Front: What does Double.parseDouble() do?
Back: Converts String to double primitive

Front: What is the JVM?
Back: Java Virtual Machine that executes bytecode

Front: What is bytecode?
Back: Compiled Java code that runs on JVM

Front: What is javac?
Back: Java compiler that creates bytecode from .java files

Front: What is the difference between stack and heap memory?
Back: Stack: local variables, Heap: objects and instance variables

Front: What is garbage collection?
Back: Automatic cleanup of unused objects in heap memory

Front: What is the String pool?
Back: Shared storage for string literals to save memory

Front: Are strings mutable in Java?
Back: No, strings are immutable (cannot be changed)

Front: What does String.equals() do?
Back: Compares the content of two strings

Front: What does String.compareTo() return?
Back: <0 if first comes before second, 0 if equal, >0 if first comes after

Front: What is a static variable?
Back: A class variable that belongs to the class itself rather than any specific instance; there is exactly one copy regardless of how many objects are created

Front: How do you access a static variable?
Back: Using the class name: ClassName.staticVariable

Front: When is a static variable initialized?
Back: When the class is first loaded into memory

Front: What is a static method?
Back: A method that belongs to the class itself and can be called without creating an instance

Front: How do you call a static method?
Back: Using the class name: ClassName.staticMethod()

Front: Can static methods access instance variables?
Back: No, static methods cannot access instance variables directly (no 'this' reference)

Front: What can static methods access?
Back: Only static variables and other static methods

Front: What are common examples of static methods?
Back: Math.sqrt(), Integer.parseInt(), System.out.println()

Front: What is the Math class used for?
Back: Provides mathematical functions and constants

Front: What are some Math class constants?
What are some Math class methods?
Back: Math.sqrt(), Math.pow(), Math.abs(), Math.max(), Math.min(), Math.random()

Front: What does Math.random() return?
Back: A random double between 0.0 (inclusive) and 1.0 (exclusive)

Front: What is the Character class used for?
Back: Provides methods for character manipulation and testing

Front: What are some Character class methods?
Back: Character.isLetter(), Character.isDigit(), Character.isUpperCase(), Character.toLowerCase(), Character.toUpperCase()

Front: What is stack memory?
Back: Memory that stores local variables and method parameters

Front: What is heap memory?
Back: Memory that stores objects and instance variables

Front: How are primitive types stored in memory?
Back: Stored directly in memory (value semantics)

Front: How are reference types stored in memory?
Back: Store memory address pointing to object (reference semantics)

Front: What is a reference variable?
Back: A variable that holds a memory address, not the actual object

Front: What happens when you assign one reference variable to another?
Back: The reference is copied, both variables point to the same object

Front: Can multiple reference variables point to the same object?
Back: Yes, multiple variables can reference the same object

Front: When does an object become eligible for garbage collection?
Back: When no references point to the object

Front: How does Java pass parameters?
Back: Java always passes parameters by value

Front: What happens when you pass a primitive parameter?
Back: A copy of the value is passed

Front: What happens when you pass a reference parameter?
Back: A copy of the reference is passed

Front: Can you change what a parameter references inside a method?
Back: No, you cannot change what the parameter references

Front: Can you modify the object that a parameter references?
Back: Yes, you can modify the object through the reference

Front: What does assignment (=) do with class type variables?
Back: Makes both variables reference the same object

Front: What does equality (==) do with class type variables?
Back: Compares memory addresses, not object contents

Front: How do you compare object contents?
Back: Use the .equals() method

Front: What is null?
Back: A special value indicating no object reference

Front: What is a NullPointerException?
Back: A runtime error that occurs when trying to use a null reference

Front: How do you prevent NullPointerException?
Back: Always check for null before using object references

Front: What are common causes of NullPointerException?
Back: Uninitialized reference variables, method returns null

Front: What is an anonymous class?
Back: A class without a name that is defined and instantiated at the same time

Front: What is the syntax for anonymous classes?
Back: new ClassName() { /* class body */ }

Front: What are use cases for anonymous classes?
Back: Event handlers, one-time implementations

Front: Can anonymous classes have constructors?
Back: No, anonymous classes cannot have constructors

Front: What is a lambda expression?
Back: A concise way to represent an anonymous function

Front: What is the basic syntax for lambda expressions?
Back: (parameters) -> expression or (parameters) -> { statements }

Front: What are use cases for lambda expressions?
Back: Functional interfaces, collections processing

Front: What is a privacy leak?
Back: When private data becomes accessible outside the class

Front: What is a common cause of privacy leaks?
Back: Returning references to private objects instead of copies

Front: How do you prevent privacy leaks?
Back: Return copies of objects, not references

Front: What is a class invariant?
Back: A statement that is always true for every object of the class

Front: How do class invariants help in design?
Back: They help define a class in a consistent and organized way

Front: What is a copy constructor?
Back: A constructor that creates a new object by copying another object of the same class

Front: What is the purpose of a copy constructor?
Back: To create independent copies of objects

Front: What is the difference between deep and shallow copy?
Back: Deep copy copies all referenced objects too; shallow copy only copies the object itself

Front: What is defensive copying?
Back: Returning copies instead of original references to prevent privacy leaks

Front: What are immutable objects?
Back: Objects that cannot be modified after creation

Front: Should getter methods return copies of mutable objects?
Back: Yes, to prevent privacy leaks

Front: What is an array?
Back: A collection of elements of the same type with fixed size

Front: How do you declare an array?
Back: type[] arrayName; or type arrayName[];

Front: How do you create an array?
Back: arrayName = new type[size];

Front: How do you declare and create an array in one line?
Back: type[] arrayName = new type[size];

Front: How do you initialize an array with values?
Back: type[] arrayName = {value1, value2, ...};

Front: How do you access an array element?
Back: arrayName[index]

Front: What is the index range for arrays?
Back: 0 to (length - 1)

Front: Do array variables hold the actual array?
Back: No, they hold references to array objects

Front: What happens when you assign one array to another?
Back: Both variables reference the same array

Front: How do you get the length of an array?
Back: arrayName.length

Front: Does Java check array bounds?
Back: Yes, Java checks array bounds at runtime

Front: What happens if you access an invalid array index?
Back: ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException is thrown

Front: What are command line arguments?
Back: Arguments passed to the main method from the command line

Front: What is the signature of the main method?
Back: public static void main(String[] args)

Front: How do you access the first command line argument?
Back: args[0]

Front: How do you get the number of command line arguments?
Back: args.length

Front: What is a partially filled array?
Back: An array that is not completely filled with elements

Front: How do you track the actual number of elements in a partially filled array?
Back: Use a separate variable to track the count

Front: What is an ArrayList?
Back: A dynamic array that can grow and shrink in size

Front: How do you import ArrayList?
Back: import java.util.ArrayList;

Front: How do you create an ArrayList?
Back: ArrayList<Type> list = new ArrayList<>();

Front: How do you add an element to the end of an ArrayList?
Back: list.add(element)

Front: How do you add an element at a specific index in ArrayList?
Back: list.add(index, element)

Front: How do you get an element from an ArrayList?
Back: list.get(index)

Front: How do you replace an element in an ArrayList?
Back: list.set(index, element)

Front: How do you remove an element from an ArrayList?
Back: list.remove(index)

Front: How do you get the size of an ArrayList?
Back: list.size()

Front: How do you remove all elements from an ArrayList?
Back: list.clear()

Front: What are variable arguments (varargs)?
Back: Method parameters that accept a variable number of arguments

Front: What is the syntax for varargs?
Back: methodName(Type... parameterName)

Front: How are varargs treated inside the method?
Back: As an array

Front: What are limitations of varargs?
Back: Only one varargs parameter per method, must be last parameter

Front: What is an enumerated type (enum)?
Back: A special class representing a group of constants

Front: What is the syntax for creating an enum?
Back: enum EnumName { VALUE1, VALUE2, VALUE3 }

Front: How do you use an enum value?
Back: EnumName.VALUE1

Front: What are some enum methods?
Back: values(), valueOf(), ordinal()

Front: What are benefits of using enums?
Back: Type safety, prevents invalid values

Front: What is a multidimensional array?
Back: An array with more than one index

Front: How do you declare a 2D array?
Back: type[][] arrayName;

Front: How do you create a 2D array?
Back: arrayName = new type[rows][columns];

Front: How do you access a 2D array element?
Back: arrayName[row][column]

Front: How do you visualize a 2D array?
Back: First index = row, second index = column

Front: How do you get the number of rows in a 2D array?
Back: arrayName.length

Front: How do you get the number of columns in a specific row?
Back: arrayName[row].length

Front: What do you use to process 2D arrays?
Back: Nested for loops

Front: What is a ragged array?
Back: A 2D array where rows have different lengths

Front: How do you create a ragged array?
Back: Create rows separately with different sizes

Front: What are use cases for ragged arrays?
Back: When data naturally has varying row lengths

Front: How do you specify 2D array parameters?
Back: methodName(type[][] parameter)

Front: How do you specify 2D array return types?
Back: type[][] methodName()

Front: What is the difference between arrays and ArrayList?
Back: Arrays have fixed size, ArrayList can grow/shrink

Front: When should you use arrays vs ArrayList?
Back: Use arrays for fixed size, ArrayList for dynamic size

Front: Can you change the size of an array after creation?
Back: No, array size is fixed after creation

Front: Can you change the size of an ArrayList after creation?
Back: Yes, ArrayList can grow and shrink dynamically

Front: What happens when you add elements beyond ArrayList capacity?
Back: ArrayList automatically increases its capacity

Front: Is ArrayList more memory efficient than arrays?
Back: No, ArrayList has overhead due to dynamic resizing

Front: Can ArrayList store primitive types directly?
Back: No, only object types (use wrapper classes for primitives)

Front: Can arrays store primitive types directly?
Back: Yes, arrays can store primitive types directly

Front: What is the default value for array elements?
Back: 0 for numbers, false for boolean, null for objects

Front: What is the default value for ArrayList elements?
Back: No default values, elements must be explicitly added
